hypotheses: Previous research (i.e. Cenoz & Valencia, 1994; Hesse et al., 2008) suggests that, once controlling for individual and familial background factors, the bilingual students will, on average, have higher scores in English as a foreign language compared to the monolingual group. Therefore we hypothesize similar advantages for the bilingual students in the present sample (Hypothesis 1a). However, as other studies have found, the expected advantage of bilingualism depends also on the individuals' proficiency in the language of instruction (i.e. Haenni Hoti et al., 2011). Because of the strong association between bilingual students' instructional language and foreign language achievement (Rauch et al., 2011), we expect an advantage for bilinguals over monolinguals if they have relatively stronger skills in the language of instruction. Furthermore, it is theorized that bilingual students with weaker majority language proficiency in contrast do not have a sufficient linguistic reservoir to support positive transfer. Therefore, we expect that they demonstrate no advantages and will lag behind their monolingual peers as well as their bilingual peers with strong majority language proficiency (Hypothesis 1b).

As an explorative hypothesis, we expect that given similar background characteristics and instructional language proficiency groups will generally differ with regard to their advantageous potential. Specifically, we test the hypothesis that combinations of languages with similar orthographic scripts (i.e., Polish-German and Turkish-German) as the dependent variable L3 will have the highest potential compared to combinations which differ in their scripts (i.e., Arabic-German and Chinese-German). (Hypothesis 2)

data.source: Assessment of Reading and Mathematics Development Study (ELEMENT) — cohort study of students in a major European city
data.wave_or_subset: Sixth-grade elementary school sample (analysis focuses on sixth grade data)
data.sample_size: 2835 students included in analyses (nested in 134 elementary school classes); original cohort representative sample N = 2946, final analytic sample N = 2835 after exclusions and use of parental/student language reports
data.notes: Data are from a representative city cohort; language-group assignment based on parent report (or student report if parent missing). Missing data handled via multiple imputation (five imputed datasets) based on a background model; nested data structure (students in classes) accounted for in analyses (MPlus type = complex). English and German measures were scaled using IRT (ConQuest) and WLEs (English WLE scaled M=100, SD=20). Group sample sizes reported for language groups (Arabic-German n=105, Chinese-German n=110, Polish-German n=57, Turkish-German n=383, heterogeneous other bilingual n=284, monolingual German n=1896).

method.description: Secondary analyses of ELEMENT cohort sixth-grade data examining relation between speaking a minority language at home (bilingualism) and English (L3) achievement. Language-group membership determined from parent (or student) report of languages regularly spoken at home. English achievement assessed via a Cloze reading test (91 items) scaled with IRT (ConQuest) producing WLE scores (mean=100, SD=20). Control variables included general cognitive abilities (composite of CFT 4-12R subtests collected in grade 4), age, gender, socio-economic status (HISEI), parental education, and cultural capital (books at home). Missing values addressed with multiple imputation (5 datasets). Regression analyses (multiple linear regression) were run in MPlus 5.21 accounting for clustering (students nested in classes) and combining results across imputations.
steps: Identify sample and assign language-group membership using parental report of languages regularly spoken at home (use student report if parent data missing).
Compute English achievement scores from Cloze test; scale items using one-parameter IRT in ConQuest and obtain WLE person estimates (scaled M=100, SD=20).

Assemble control variables: general cognitive abilities (composite of CFT4-12R verbal and figural analogies), age, gender, HISEI (highest parental ISEI), parental education, and number of books at home (cultural capital).
Handle missing data via multiple imputation (five imputed datasets) based on a background model including individual and classroom-level factors.
Fit multiple linear regression models in MPlus 5.21 using type=complex to account for nesting of students within classes; combine results across imputations (option type=imputation).

Estimate models incrementally: (A) uncontrolled bilingual vs. monolingual; (B) add individual controls (cognitive ability, age, gender); (C) add family controls (HISEI, parental education, cultural capital); (D) add German reading proficiency (instructional language proficiency) and inspect group-specific effects.
Interpret coefficients, significance, variance explained (R2), and examine group differences across bilingual language groups and across German proficiency levels.
method.models: Multiple linear regression models (OLS) estimated with clustering adjustment (MPlus complex) across five multiply-imputed datasets; models include dummy variables for bilingual status, dummy variables for bilingual German proficiency levels, and dummy variables for specific bilingual language groups; IRT scoring (one-parameter) used for test scaling.
method.outcome_variable: English language achievement (Cloze test WLE score; scaled mean = 100, SD = 20)
method.independent_variables: Primary: bilingual group membership (binary) or subgroup indicators (Arabic-German, Chinese-German, Polish-German, Turkish-German, Other bilingual); German instructional language proficiency groups (five levels derived from German reading test WLEs).
method.control_variables: General cognitive abilities (composite of CFT4-12R subtests), age, gender, socio-economic status (HISEI), parental education, cultural capital (number of books at home); models additionally control for German reading proficiency in final models.
method.tools_software: ConQuest (IRT scaling, WLEs) and MPlus 5.21 (multiple imputation combination and regression analyses, complex survey adjustment).

results.summary: Descriptively, German monolinguals had higher raw English scores than bilinguals; however, after controlling for background variables (cognitive ability, age, gender, socio-economic status, parental education, and cultural capital), bilingual group membership was positively associated with English achievement. Instructional language (German) proficiency was the strongest predictor of English achievement; when German proficiency was controlled, most bilingual subgroups (Chinese-German, Polish-German, Turkish-German, and heterogeneous other bilinguals) showed significant advantages in English relative to monolingual peers, while Arabic-German students did not show an advantage. Overall, bilingualism added a small but significant amount of explained variance relative to background variables; German proficiency explained a substantial additional portion of variance.
